choices.text: That activate T cells in a specific and controlled manner
Produced by antigen-presenting cells to enhance presentation capabilities
Produced by T cells as a way of increasing the antigen activation they receive from antigen-presenting cells
That activates T cells in a nonspecific and uncontrolled manner

questions.solution:
• Superantigens (SAgs) are a class of antigens that result in excessive activation of the immune system. Specifically it causes non-specific activation of T-cells resulting in polyclonal T cell activation and massive cytokine release.
  • Superantigens do not get processed by an antigen- presenting cell (APC).
  • They attach directly to the MHC-II a1 domain and &beta variable chain of TCR.
  • There are two types of super-antigens: (i) endogenous, which are intracellular (e.g., virus) and (ii) exogenous, which extracellular (e.g., bacteria).

Microbial superantigens are medium-sized proteins (MW 22-29 kDa) characterised by high resistance to proteases.

They initiate the release of (IL- 2), which results in massive proliferation of T lymphocytes. This ultimately leads to further release of a variety of cytokines which have profound effect on the immune system.

Option (B): Produced by antigen-presenting cells to enhance presentation capabilities - They are protein molecules (e.g., staphylococcal enterotoxins) that activate very large numbers of T lymphocytes irrespective of their antigenic specificity. Super antigens are actually a part of bacteria or produced from bacteria but not by antigen presenting cells.

  • Option (C): Produced by T cells as a way of increasing the antigen activation they receive from antigen-presenting cells - Super antigens are actually a part of bacteria or produced from bacteria but not by T cells.

Reference:Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Chapter 10, Pg 195

questions.text: A women presents to the emergency with vaginal bleeding on examination her BP â€“ 80/50, rash is present on the upper half of the body and vaginal tampons are found if this reaction is due to antigen what would be the binding site of that antigen on MHC molecule
questions.solution:
the patient described in the above question is in shock due to staphylococcal enterotoxins. The is suffering from TSS (staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome). The biggest clue in the above question is vaginal tampons.

TSS - fever, vomiting, diarrhea, rash, desquamation, shock, end-organ failure. TSS results in  ↑AST, ↑ALT,  ↑bilirubin. Associated with prolonged use of vaginal tampons or nasal packing. Compare with Streptococcus pyogenes TSS (a toxic shock–like syndrome associated with painful skin infection).

TSS is due to superantigens.

Superantigens bind simultaneously to the Vβ domain of a T-cell receptor and to the α chain of a class II MHC molecule.

Reference:Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Chapter 10, Pg 93
